India’s air rivals China’s as deadliest in the world, says study india Updated: Feb 14, 2017 17:40 IST AFP, New Delhi Students cover faces amid heavy smog in New Delhi.(Sushil Kumar/HT Photo) 
India’s air now rivals China’s as the world’s deadliest, according to a new study published on Tuesday amid warnings that efforts to curb pollution from coal won’t yield results any time soon. 
India’s notoriously poor air quality causes nearly 1.1 million premature deaths every year, almost on par with China, concluded a joint report by two US-based health research institutes. 
But where deaths linked to air pollution in China have steadied in recent years, the rate has soared in India where smog readings in major cities routinely eclipse safe exposure levels. 
India has recorded a nearly 50% increase in premature deaths linked to PM2.5 -- fine particles that lodge deep in the lungs -- between 1990 and 2015, the report found. 
“India now approaches China in the number of deaths attributable to PM2.5,” said the report by the Health Effects Institute and the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Read more Air pollution choking India, UP home to 5 most polluted cities in the country 
Anti-pollution steps in China -- which jostles with India for the unenviable title of world’s most polluted country -- has seen the number of smog-related deaths largely stabilise since 2005. 
In India, that number has steadily climbed from an estimated 737,400 deaths a year in 1990 to 1.09 million in 2015. 
India and neighbouring Bangladesh have experienced the steepest increases in pollution since 2010 “and now have the highest PM2.5 concentrations” in the world, the report said. People wearing masks cycle past Tiananmen Gate during smog after a red alert was issued for heavy air pollution in Beijing, China in December, 2016. (Reuters Photo) 
Pollution in New Delhi in November reached crisis levels, with crop burning, car exhaust, dust and coal plants blamed for the record smog. 
The government shuttered schools and temporarily closed a coal-fired power plant as a stop gap, but experts say the energy-hungry nation will need to do more if it’s to clean the air for India’s 1.25 billion people. Read more China to spend $ 2.6 billion to fight Beijing pollution this year 
“Coal isn’t going to go away very fast. Coal-based pollution in the environment will always be very significant in India,” Sumant Sinha, chairman of Indian clean energy firm ReNew Power said. “Renewables are not going to be expanding fast enough for us to be able to impact that particular problem. Unless all of those (factors) are also brought under control, I don’t think it’s going to come anywhere close to really solving the problem.” tags
